channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fears of Greek Debt Default Overshadow E.U. Gathering
item.description: European Union leaders meeting in Brussels were confronted with the possibility of a Greek default, and exit from the eurozone, and possibly the bloc.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Argentine Prosecutor Urges Reopening of Case Against President
item.description: The prosecutor said an investigation into allegations against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and other officials, dismissed by a judge last month, should resume.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Israel’s Netanyahu Reopens Door to Palestinian State, but White House Is Unimpressed
item.description: In his first interview since his re-election victory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel walked back his rejection of a two-state solution.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: World Briefing: French Proposal on Models’ Weights Clashes With Labor Laws, Opponents Say
item.description: A parliamentary committee rejected two provisions of an anorexia prevention measure but left open the possibility that an amended version could be approved later.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and DAPHNE ANGLES

item.title: Battle for Aden Airport Stokes Fears of Wider Conflict in Yemen
item.description: At least three people were killed as rival factions fought for control of the airport, which was forced to shut down, according to witnesses and security officials.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Rival factions fought for control of the airport in Aden, Yemen, on Thursday, forcing it to shut down.

item.title: World Briefing: Japanese Police Arrest Man Accused of Threatening to Bomb U.S. Embassy and Base
item.description: The police said the man, Mitsuyoshi Kamiya, who was arrested on Okinawa, confessed to making bomb threats in three phone calls this month.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Suspected Accomplices Arrested in Tunisian Museum Attack
item.description: Officials said that no link had been established between the two gunmen who carried out Wednesday’s rampage and any known terrorist organization.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Police kept watch outside the National Bardo Museum on Thursday, as officials said they had found no ties between the gunmen responsible for an attack there and any known terrorist group.

item.title: Powerful Afghan Police Chief Killed in Kabul
item.description: Matiullah Khan, one of the wealthiest and most powerful men in southern Afghanistan, was killed on Wednesday in a targeted suicide bombing.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Israel’s Netanyahu, Softening Pre-Election Statement, Reopens Door to Palestinian State
item.description: In his first interview since his re-election victory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel walked back his rejection of a two-state solution.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Social Media Images of Antiterrorism Rally in Tunis
item.description: Tunisians marched hours after an assault by militants on a museum in the capital, Tunis, left at least 19 dead.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MacKEY

item.title: In Security Meeting, Japan and China Inch Toward Mending Ties
item.description: The two nations, holding their first meeting on security issues in four years, discussed the creation of a hotline to ease tensions in the East China Sea.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Letter From Europe: For Africa, a Pivotal Plane Crash
item.description: Students of modern Africa exploring the dramas of the postcolonial era might start their quest for pointers in the period surrounding the death of Dag Hammarskjold.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: ISIS Suspected of Genocide Against Yazidis in Iraq, U.N. Panel Says
item.description: Rights investigators reported that the pattern of attacks against the religious minority pointed to the intention of Islamic State militants “to destroy the Yazidi as a group.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yazidis lined up for food at a refugee camp in Khanke, Iraq, in August.

item.title: Kerry Says Difficult Issues Persist in Nuclear Talks With Iran
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said during a break in talks in Lausanne, Switzerland, that “we are pushing some tough issues, but we made progress.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: 2 Associates of Ex-Security Chief to Face Trial Over Bribery in China
item.description: The news came a day after the country’s highest court suggested that the offenses of the disgraced security official might have extended to political plotting.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Issues New Guidelines to Reduce Logging
item.description: Under a government plan, China will reduce commercial harvesting of planted forests by 20 percent and eliminate logging on state-owned natural forests by 2020.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A timber-processing site in Shenyang, in the northeastern Chinese province of Liaoning.

item.title: At War Blog: Testing a Few Good Women for Combat
item.description: This month, the Marine Corps will experiment with a test of women’s performance in combat arms. It’s historic, but not a first: Teresa Fazio and seven other women took part in a similar test in 2000.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: TERESA FAZIO
item.media:description: Teresa Fazio at Twentynine Palms, Calif., in 2000.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As China Prospers, the Military Recruiter’s Job Gets Harder
item.description: The country’s armed forces are increasingly in need of educated soldiers, sailors and airmen to operate its rapidly growing arsenal of advanced weapons.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A military honor guard prepares to welcome Prime Minister Matteo Renzi outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on June 11, 2014.

item.title: Tunisia Has Found No Terrorist Links to Gunmen in Museum Attack
item.description: Officials have identified the attackers, who killed at least 20 people at the National Bardo Museum, as Yassine Laabidi and Hatem Khachnaoui.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Indonesia Postpones Drug-Case Executions Amid Legal Challenges
item.description: Government officials said it could take months to resolve appeals by two Australians and several others sentenced to die for drug crimes.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
